This manual describes version &appversion; of &app;.
Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, follow the directions in the GNOME Feedback Page.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables you to create and edit text files. You can use &app; plugins to perform a variety of tasks related to text-editing from within the &app; window.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Accessories Text Editor .
Type gedit, then press Return.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed:
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to work with files in &app;.
The toolbar contains a subset of the commands that you can access from the menubar.
The display area contains the text of the file that you are editing.
The output window displays the output returned by the Shell command plugin and the Compare files plugin.
The statusbar displays information about current &app; activity and contextual information about the menu items.

sect2.title: To Open a File
sect2.para:
To open a file, choose File Open
to display the Open File dialog. Select the file that you want to open, then click OK. The file is displayed in the &app; window.

You can open multiple files in &app;. The application displays one file at a time in the application window. The application adds a tab for each open file to the window. To display another open file, click on the tab that corresponds to the file. To create a new &app; window for each file that is open, drag the tab corresponding to each file to the desktop background.
You can also use the Documents menu to move between the open files. You can choose Documents Move to New Window to move a document to a new &app; window.

The application records the paths and filenames of the five most recent files that you edited and displays the files as menu items on the File menu. You can also click on the
Shows Recent Files menu icon.
icon on the toolbar to display the list of recent files.

sect2.title: To Open Multiple Files from a Command Line
sect2.para: You can run &app; from a command line and open a single file or multiple files. To open multiple files from a command line, type the following command, then press Return:
When the application starts, the files that you specify are displayed in the &app; window.
For more information on how to run &app; from a command line, see &app;1.

sect2.title: To Create a New File
sect2.para: To create a new file, choose File New . The application displays a new file in the &app; window.

sect2.title: To Save a File
sect2.para: You can save files in the following ways:

listitem.para: To save changes to an existing file, choose File Save or click Save on the toolbar.
To save a new file or to save an existing file under a new filename, choose File Save As . Enter a name for the file in the Save As dialog box, then click OK.
To save all of the files that are currently open in &app;, choose Documents Save All .

sect2.title: To Edit Text
sect2.para: You can edit the text of a file in the following ways:

listitem.para: Type new text from the keyboard.
Use the Delete key to delete text.
Use the Cut, Copy, Paste, and Delete menu items on the Edit menu to edit text.

sect2.para: You can perform any of the following actions on the selected text:

listitem.para: To copy the selected text to a buffer, choose Edit Copy .
To delete the selected text from the file and move the selected text to a buffer, choose Edit Cut .
To permanently delete the selected text from the file, choose Edit Delete .
To insert the contents of the buffer at the cursor position, choose Edit Paste . You must cut or copy text before you can paste text into the file.
To select all of the text in a file, choose Edit Select All .

sect2.title: To Undo or Redo Edits
sect2.para: To undo an edit, choose Edit Undo . To redo an edit, choose Edit Redo . The number of previous edits that you can undo is determined by the Set limit on undo actions to setting in the tabbed section of the Preferences dialog. By default, the number of actions that you can undo is 25.

sect2.title: To Find Text
sect2.para: To search a file for a string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Find to display the Find dialog.
Type the string that you want to find, in the Search for field.
You can include the following escape sequences:
Use this escape sequence to specify a new line
Use this escape sequence to specify a tab character
Use this escape sequence to specify a carriage return
Select the Case sensitive option to only find occurrences of the string that match the case of the text that you type.
Select the Match entire word only option to only find occurrences of the string that match the entire words of the text that you type.
Select the Wrap around option to search to the end of the file and then continue the search from the beginning of the file.
Click Find to search the file for the first occurrence of the string. If &app; finds the string, the application moves the cursor to the string, and selects the string.
To find the next occurrence of the string, click Find.
To finish the search, click Close.

sect2.title: To Find and Replace Text
sect2.para: To search a file for a string, and replace the string with an alternative string, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Replace to display the Replace dialog.
Type the string that you want to find, in the Search for field.
You can include the following escape sequences:
Use this escape sequence to specify a new line
Use this escape sequence to specify a tab character
Use this escape sequence to specify a carriage return
Type the string that you want to use to replace the string that you find, in the Replace with field.
Select the Case sensitive option to only find occurrences of the string that match the case of the text that you enter.
Select the Match entire word only option to only find occurrences of the string that match the entire words of the text that you type.
Select the Wrap around option to search to the end of the file and then continue the search from the beginning of the file.
Click Find to search the file for the first occurrence of the string. If &app; finds the string, the application moves the cursor to the string, and selects the string.
Click on Replace to replace the occurrence of the string with the text that you typed in the Replace with field. Click on Replace All to replace all occurrences of the string.
To find the next occurrence of the string, click Find.
To finish the search, click Close.

sect2.title: To Open a File from a URI
sect2.para: To open a file from a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), perform one of the following steps:

listitem.para:
Choose File Open Location
to display the Open Location dialog. Enter the URI of the file that you want to open, then click Open.

Type gedit URI at a command line, where URI is the URI of the file that you want to open, then press Return. Valid types of URI include http:, ftp:, file:, and all of the methods supported by gnome-vfs.

sect2.para: The application opens the file located at the URI in read-only mode.

sect2.title: To Pipe the Output of a Command to a File
sect2.para: You can use &app; to pipe the output of a command to a text file. For example, to pipe the output of an ls command to a text file, type ls | gedit, then press Return.
The output of the ls command is displayed in a new text file in the &app; window.
Alternatively, you can use the Shell command plugin to pipe command output to the current file. For information about how to use the Shell command plugin, see .

sect2.title: To Go to a Specific Line
sect2.para: To go to a specific line in the current file, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Go to Line to display the Go to Line dialog.
Type the number of the line that you want to move the cursor to in the Line number field.
Click Go to Line. The application moves the cursor to the line number that you specify.
To close the Go to Line dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: To Change the Input Mode
sect2.para: To change the input mode, right-click in the text window, then select Input Methods. The Insert Unicode control character menu item provides character layout options that are useful for working with non-Latin character sets.

sect2.title: To Print a File
sect2.para: You can use &app; to perform the following print operations:

listitem.para: Print a file to a printer.
Print the output of the print command to a file.

sect2.para: If you print to a file, &app; sends the output of the file to a pre-press format file. The most common pre-press formats are PostScript and Portable Document Format (PDF).
To preview the pages that you want to print, choose File Print Preview .
To print the current file to a printer or a file, choose File Print to display the Print dialog.
The Print dialog allows you to specify the following print options:

listitem.para: Select one of the following options to determine how many pages to print:
Select this option to print all of the pages in the file.
Select this option to print the selected text only. This option is only available if you selected text.
Use this spin box to specify the number of copies of the file that you want to print.
If you are printing multiple copies of the file, select this option to collate the printed copies.
Use this drop-down list to select the printer to which you want to print the file.
Use this drop-down list to select the printer settings. To configure the printer, click Configure.

Use this drop-down list to select the print destination. To print the file to a printer, choose lpr. To print the file to a print file, choose File. If you select File, type the name of the output file in the text box provided. To print a file to a location of your choice, choose Custom. Type the location you want in the Custom text box.
Use this drop-down list to select the size of the paper to which you want to print the file.
Use this spin box to specify the width of the paper. Use the adjacent drop-down list to change the measurement unit for specifying the paper size.
Use this spin box to specify the height of the paper.
Use this drop-down list to select the orientation of the paper in the printer.
Use this drop-down list to select the page orientation.
Use this drop-down list to select the page layout. A preview of each layout that you select is displayed in the Preview area.

sect2.title: To Customize the Toolbar and Statusbar
sect2.para: To display or hide the toolbar, choose View Toolbar . To customize how &app; displays the toolbar, choose View Customize Toolbar , then select one of the following menu items:

listitem.para: Display the default toolbar.
Display icons only.
Display icons and text.
Display icons, and display text beside some of the icons.

sect2.para: To display or hide the statusbar, choose View Statusbar . To customize how &app; displays the statusbar, choose View Customize Statusbar , then select one of the following menu items:

listitem.para: Display the line number and column number where the cursor is located.
Display the editing mode. If the editor is in insert mode, the statusbar contains the word INS. If the editor is in overwrite mode, the statusbar contains the word OVR.

sect2.para: To display or hide the output window, choose View Output Window .

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, choose
Edit Preferences . The Preferences dialog contains the following categories:

sect2.title: Editor
sect2.para: The Editor category is subdivided into the following subcategories:

listitem.para: Select this option to use the default system font for the text in the &app; text window.
This field displays the font that &app; uses to display text. Click on the button to specify the font type, style, and size to use for text.
Select this option to use the default theme colors in the &app; text window.
Click on the Selected text color button to display the color selector dialog. Select a color to use to display selected text.
Click on the Selection color button to display the color selector dialog. Select a background color to use to highlight a text selection.
Use this spin box to specify the width of the space that &app; inserts when you press the Tab key.
Select this option to specify that &app; inserts spaces instead of a tab character when you press the Tab key.
Select this option to wrap text onto the next line, at a character level, when you reach the text window boundary.

term.guilabel: Do not split words over two lines

listitem.para: Select this option to wrap text onto the next line, at a word level, when you reach the text window boundary.
Select this option to specify that the next line starts at the indentation level of the current line.
Select this option to display line numbers on the left side of the &app; window.

A character encoding is a method of converting bytes to characters. Different encodings may convert the same byte sequence into different characters, or may produce invalid output. If you open a file using the same encoding as that used to create the file, all characters are displayed as intended. However, if you open a file using a different encoding, some characters may not be displayed correctly, or an error may be returned.

By default, &app; uses UTF-8 encoding to try to open a file. UTF-8 encoding can be used for multilingual texts, as UTF-8 covers almost all known alphabets and character sets. If the file is not a valid UTF-8 file, &app; tries to open the file by using the encoding for the current locale. If this also fails, &app; tries to use an encoding from the Supported encodings list, starting at the top of the list.
To modify the contents of the Supported encodings list, use the following buttons:
Click on Add to add an encoding to the list.
Click on Remove to remove an encoding from the list.
Click on Up to move an encoding to a higher position in the list.
Click on Down to move an encoding to a lower position in the list.

term.guilabel: Create a backup copy of files before saving

listitem.para: Select this option to create a backup copy of a file each time you save the file. The backup copy of the file contains a tilde (~) at the end of the filename.
Select this option to automatically save the current file at regular intervals. Use the spin box to specify the interval at which you want to save the file.
Select one of the following save options:
Select this option to save files using UTF-8 encoding.

para.guilabel: Use current locale's encoding if possible

listitem.para: Select this option to save files using the current locale. You can set up locales for different input methods.

para.guilabel: Use original file encoding if possible

listitem.para: Select this option to save a file using the current locale if the file was already saved in the current locale.
Select one of the following save options for new files:
Select this option to save new files using UTF-8 encoding.

para.guilabel: Use current locale's encoding if possible

listitem.para: Select this option to save new files using the current locale. You can set up locales for different input methods.

term.guilabel: Set limit on undo actions to

listitem.para: Select this option to set a limit on the number of editing actions that you can undo. Use the spin box to specify the maximum number of actions that you can undo.

sect2.title: Print
sect2.para: The Print category is subdivided into the following subcategories:

listitem.para: Select this option to include a header on each page that you print. You cannot configure the header.
Select this option to automatically wrap text at a word level when you print a file. The application counts wrapped lines as one line for line numbering purposes.
Select this option to include line numbers when you print a file. Use the spin box to specify how often to print the line numbers, for example every 5 lines, every 10 lines, and so on.

sect3.title: Fonts

listitem.para: Click on this button to select the font to use to print the body text of a file.
Click on this button to select the font to use to print the headers in a file.
Click on this button to select a font to use to print line numbers.

sect3.para: To reset the fonts to the default fonts for printing a file from &app; click on the Restore Default Fonts button.

sect2.title: Plugins
sect2.para: For information about how to use the Plugins category of the Preferences dialog, see .

sect1.title: Working with Plugins
sect1.para: A plugin is a supplementary program that enhances the functionality of an application. The &app; plugins enable you to perform a variety of functions related to text editing from within the &app; window. The following table lists the &app; plugins.

entry.para: Displays a dialog that contains an ASCII table. You can use the ASCII table to insert characters into a file.
Compares two files and displays the differences between the files in the Output window. This plugin uses the diff command to compare the files.
Opens the log messages associated with CVS commit commands.
Counts the number of lines, words, characters with spaces, characters without spaces, and bytes in the current file. The plugin displays the results in a Document Statistics dialog.
Indents the selected lines, or removes the indentation from the selected lines.
Inserts the current date and time into a file.
Displays the text output of a shell command in the output window.
Checks the spelling in the selected text. You can configure &app; to check the spelling automatically, or you can check the spelling manually, in the specified language.
Displays a window that contains a list of common tags. You can use the window to insert a tag into a file.
Inserts the username of the current user into the file.

sect2.title: To Load &app; Plugins
sect2.para:
To load &app; plugins, choose
Edit Preferences . Within the Plugins category, click on the Manager subcategory. The Manager subcategory displays the following information:

listitem.para: A list of the plugins that you can use with &app;.
A Configure plugin button. You can use this button to open a configuration dialog for the plugins that you can configure. For example, see and .
A brief description of each plugin. To display a description, select the plugin from the list of plugins.
Details about the author of the plugin and the name of the module.

sect2.para: To load a plugin, select the check box next to the name of the plugin. The &app; application adds the plugin to the appropriate &app; menu, as described in the following table.
To close the Preferences dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: To Remove &app; Plugins
sect2.para: A plugin remains loaded when you quit &app;.

To remove &app; plugins, choose
Edit Preferences . Within the Plugins category, click on the Manager subcategory. To remove a plugin, deselect the check box next to the name of the plugin.
To close the Preferences dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: ASCII Table Plugin
sect2.para: The ASCII table plugin displays a dialog that contains an ASCII table. You can use the ASCII table to insert characters into a file. To use the ASCII table plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the ASCII table plugin.
Choose View ASCII Table to display the ASCII Table dialog.
To close the ASCII Table dialog without inserting an ASCII character, click Close. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
Scroll through the list to find the character that you require, then click on that character to select it.
Click on Insert char to insert the character at the cursor position in the current file.
When you finish entering ASCII characters, click Close to close the ASCII Table dialog.

sect2.title: Compare Files Plugin
sect2.para: The Compare files plugin compares two files and displays the differences between the files in the Output window. This plugin uses the diff command to compare the files. To use the Compare files plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Compare files plugin.

Choose Tools Compare Files . When you choose this option for the first time, you are prompted to confirm the location of the diff command. You are not prompted for this location again. See for information about how to change this location later.
Click OK to display the Compare Files dialog. To close the Compare Files dialog without comparing any files, click Cancel. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
Specify the files that you want to compare. To specify an open file, select the file from the drop-down list. To specify a closed file, enter the location of the file in the text box.
To ignore changes in the amount of white space, select the Ignore blanks option.
To use the unified output format, showing three lines of context, select the Use the unified output format option.
Click on Compare to compare the contents of the specified files. The command output is displayed in the output window.

sect2.para: For more information, see diff1.

sect3.title: To Configure the Compare Files Plugin
sect3.para: To change the location of the command that the Compare files plugin uses, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Edit Preferences .
Within the Plugins category, click on the Manager subcategory.
Select the Compare files plugin.
Click on Configure plugin to display the Set program location dialog.
To close the Set program location dialog without making any changes, click Cancel. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
Specify the location of the diff command in the Location to search for text box.
Click OK to close the Set program location dialog.
To close the Preferences dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: CVS ChangeLog Plugin
sect2.para: The CVS ChangeLog plugin opens the log messages associated with CVS commit commands. This plugin allows you to easily paste text into the commit message from the ChangeLog file. To use the CVS ChangeLog plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Set the environment variable CVSEDITOR to &app;. For example, if you are using the bash shell, run the following command at the operating system prompt: export CVSEDITOR=&app;
Commit a file to CVS in the usual way. A &app; window opens, to allow you to enter the commit message.
Load the CVS ChangeLog plugin.
Choose File Open CVS ChangeLogs to open all of the ChangeLog files referenced in the commit message. &app; opens each ChangeLog file in a new tab.
Copy the ChangeLog entries (that you want to add to the commit message) from the &app; ChangeLog files.
Insert the copied ChangeLog entries in the &app; commit message tab.
Save your changes to the commit message, then close all files.
Quit &app;.

sect2.title: Document Statistics Plugin
sect2.para: The Document Statistics plugin counts the number of lines, words, characters with spaces, characters without spaces, and bytes in the current file. The plugin displays the results in a Document Statistics dialog. To use the Document Statistics plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Document Statistics plugin.
Choose Tools Document Statistics to display the Document Statistics dialog. The Document Statistics dialog display the following information about the file:
Number of Lines in the current document.
Number of Words in the current document.
Number of Characters (with spaces) in the current document.
Number of Characters (no spaces) in the current document.
Number of Bytes in the current document.
You can continue to update the &app; file while the Document Statistics dialog is open. To refresh the contents of the Document Statistics dialog, click on the Update button.
To close the Document Statistics dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: Indent Lines Plugin
sect2.para: The Indent lines plugin indents the selected lines, or removes the indentation from the selected lines. To use the Indent lines plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Indent lines plugin.
Select the lines that you want to indent. To indent or unindent a single line, place the cursor anywhere on that line.
Choose Edit Indent .
To remove the indentation, select the lines and choose Edit Unindent .

sect2.title: Insert Date/Time Plugin
sect2.para: The Insert Date/Time plugin inserts the current date and time into a file. To use the Insert Date/Time plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Insert Date/Time plugin.
Choose Edit Insert Date and Time .

If you have not configured the Insert Date/Time plugin to automatically insert the date/time without prompting you for the format, &app; displays the Insert Date and Time dialog. Select the appropriate date/time format from the list. Click on Insert to close the Insert Date and Time dialog; &app; inserts the date/time at the cursor position in the current file.

If you have configured &app; to use one particular date/time format, the Insert Date and Time dialog is not displayed; the date/time is automatically entered at the cursor position in the current file.
See for information about how to configure the Insert Date/Time plugin.

sect3.title: To Configure the Insert Date/Time Plugin
sect3.para: To configure the Insert Date/Time plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Edit Preferences .
Within the Plugins category, click on the Manager subcategory.
Select the Insert Date/Time plugin.
Click on Configure plugin to display the Configure insert date/time plugin dialog.
To close the Configure insert date/time plugin dialog without making any changes, click Cancel. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
Select one of the options, as follows:
To specify the date/time format each time you insert the date/time, select the Prompt for a format option.

To use the same &app;-provided date/time format each time you insert the date/time, select the Use the selected format option, then select the appropriate format from the list. When you select this option, &app; will not prompt you for the date/time format when you choose Edit Insert Date/Time .

To use the same customized date/time format each time you insert the date/time, select the Use custom format option, then enter the appropriate format in the text box. For more information about how to specify a custom format, see strftime3. When you select this option, &app; will not prompt you for the date/time format when you choose Edit Insert Date/Time .
Click OK to close the Configure insert date/time plugin dialog.
To close the Preferences dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: Shell Command Plugin
sect2.para: The Shell Command plugin allows you to capture the output from a shell command in &app;, by displaying the text output of the shell command in the output window. To use the Shell command plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Shell command plugin.
Choose Tools Run Command to display the Run Command dialog.
To close the Run Command dialog without running a shell command, click Close. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
Type the shell command that you want to execute in the Command field.
You can include the following special characters:
Use these special characters to specify the filename of the current active document, including the path.
Use these special characters to specify the filename of the current active document, without the path; in this case, &app; looks for the file in the Working directory.
Edit the Working directory field if necessary. By default, the Shell command plugin executes the command you specify in the current directory.

Select the Show results in Output Window option to display the results of the command in the Output window. If you do not select this option, &app; discards the results of the command. By default, the Show results in Output Window option is selected.
Click Run. The Shell command plugin executes the command and inserts the text output into the output window.
Use the Shift key to select the text in the output window.
Click on Copy selected lines to copy the selected text into the buffer.
Choose Edit Paste to paste the selected text into the file.
Click on Close the output window to close the output window.

sect2.title: Sort Plugin
sect2.para: The Sort plugin sorts the selected text.

note.para: You cannot undo the Sort operation, so you should save the file before performing the sort. To revert to the saved version of the file after the sort operation, choose File Revert .

sect2.para: To use the Sort plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Sort plugin.
Choose Edit Sort to display the Sort dialog.
To close the Sort dialog without performing a sort operation, click Cancel. To display context-sensitive help, click Help.
To arrange the text in reverse sort order, select the Reverse order option.
To delete duplicate lines, select the Remove duplicates option.
To ignore case sensitivity, select the Ignore case option.
To specify the start position of the sort, select the appropriate column from the Start at column spin box.
To perform the sort operation, click on Sort.

sect2.title: Spell Checker Plugin
sect2.para: The Spell checker plugin checks the spelling in the selected text. You can configure &app; to check the spelling automatically, or you can check the spelling manually, in the specified language. The language setting, and the autocheck spelling properties, apply per document. To use the Spell checker plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Spell checker plugin.
Choose Tools Set Language to display the Set language dialog. Select the appropriate language from the list. Click OK to close the Set language dialog.

To check the spelling automatically, choose Tools Autocheck Spelling . To unset the automatic spell check, choose Tools Autocheck Spelling again. When automatic spell checking is set, an icon is displayed beside the Autocheck Spelling menu item. Automatic spell checking is unset by default, each time &app; starts.
Unknown spellings are displayed in a different color, and underlined. Right-click on an unknown spelling, then select Spelling Suggestions from the popup menu:
To replace the unknown spelling with another spelling in the list, select the replacement spelling from the Spelling Suggestions popup menu.
To add the unknown spelling to your personal dictionary, select Spelling Suggestions Add .

To ignore all occurrences of the unknown spelling, so that they are no longer flagged as unknown but are not added to your personal dictionary, select Spelling Suggestions Ignore All . The unknown word is only ignored in the current &app; session; the word will be flagged again in a new &app; session.
To check the spelling manually, choose Tools Check Spelling .
If there are no spelling errors, an Information dialog displays a message stating that the document does not contain misspelled words. Click OK to close the Information dialog.
If there are spelling errors, the Check Spelling dialog is displayed:
The Misspelled word is displayed at the top of the dialog.

A suggested known spelling is displayed in the Change to text box. You can replace this with another known spelling by selecting a spelling from the Suggestions list, or you can enter text directly into the Change to text box.

To check the spelling of the text in the Change to text box, click on Check Word. If this is a known word, the Suggestions list is replaced with the text (correct spelling). If it is not a known word, new entries appear in the Suggestions list.

To ignore the current occurrence of the unknown word, click on Ignore. To ignore all occurrences of the unknown word, click on Ignore All. The unknown word is only ignored in the current &app; session; the word will be flagged again in a new &app; session.

To change the current occurrence of the unknown word to the text in the Change to text box, click on Change. To change all occurrences of the unknown word to the text in the Change to text box, click on Change All.
To add the unknown word to your personal dictionary, click on Add Word.
To close the Check Spelling dialog, click Close.

sect2.title: Tag List Plugin
sect2.para: The Tag List plugin displays a window that contains a list of common tags. You can use the window to insert a tag into a file. To use the Tag List plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the Tag List plugin.
Choose View Tag List to display the Tag list plugin window.
Select the appropriate tag category from the drop-down list; for example, HTML - Tags.
Scroll through the tag list to find the required tag.
To insert a tag at the cursor position in the current file, double-click on the tag in the tag list. You can also insert a tag as follows:
To insert a tag in the current file and change the focus from the Tag list plugin window to the editor window, press Enter.
To insert a tag in the current file and maintain the focus on the Tag list plugin window, press ShiftEnter.
To close the Tag list plugin window, click on the Close Window button in the window frame. Alternatively, press CtrlW when the focus is on the Tag list plugin window.

sect2.title: User Name Plugin
sect2.para: The User name plugin inserts the username of the current user into the file. To use the User name plugin, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Load the User name plugin.
Choose Edit Insert User Name to insert your username at the cursor position in the current file.
